title: World Vaccination Day: How to register your newborn for free government vaccines
author: SECTIONS World Vaccination Day How
description: As the world celebrates World Vaccination Day, India's Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) continues to play a vital role in protecting newborns and young children from life-threatening diseases. The UIP provides free vaccines to newborns, ensuring that they are protected against diseases such as tuberculosis, hepatitis B, polio, and pneumococcal disease, among others.
cleaned_text: Immunization Programme (UIP) continues to play an important role in protecting newborns and young children from life-threatening diseases. Under [mission Indradhanush](/topic/mission-indradhanush), the government is providing free [vaccination](/topic/vaccination)to newborns, ensuring that they are protected against diseases such as tuberculosis, hepatitis B, polio, and pneumococcal disease, among others. These vaccines are administered at various stages of the child's development, starting from birth until the age of five years. Here are some of the free vaccines provided by the Indian government to newborns: BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) [Vaccine](/topic/vaccine): This vaccine is given at birth to protect against tuberculosis. Hepatitis B Vaccine: The first dose of this vaccine is given at birth, followed by two more doses at 6 weeks and 14 weeks to protect against hepatitis B. Polio Vaccine: The first dose of oral polio vaccine (OPV) is given at birth, followed by doses at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, and a booster dose at 16-24 months of age to protect against polio. Pentavalent Vaccine: This vaccine is a combination of Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccines. It is given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age to protect against these diseases. Rotavirus Vaccine: This vaccine is given orally at 6 and 14 weeks of age to protect against rotavirus, which can cause severe diarrhea in infants. Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine: This vaccine is given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age to protect against pneumococcal disease, which can cause pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis. Measles-Rubella (MR) Vaccine: This vaccine is given at 9-12 months of age to protect against measles and rubella. Here's how you can register your child for the UIP: 1. Visit the nearest Primary Health Center (PHC) or government hospital and register the child for the UIP. Provide your child's name, date of birth, and other personal details to register them for the program. 2. Mobile application: The Indian government has launched a mobile application called 'Immunization'to register your child under UIP. The application can be downloaded from the Google Play Store or Apple App Store. 3. Anganwadi Centers: You can also register your child for the UIP at Anganwadi centers, which are government-run child development centers that provide various services, including immunization. The date and time slot will be allocated to you after the registration process is completed. It is to note that all these vaccination are free of cost and included in your child's rights.
